journal-title-group.journal-title: American journal on intellectual and developmental disabilities

title-group.article-title: Validating and Applying the CSBS-ITC in Neurogenetic Syndromes

contrib-group.aff: Department of Psychological Sciences, Purdue University

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Bridgette Tonnsen, Ph.D., Department of Psychological Sciences, Purdue University, 703 Third Street, West Lafayette, IN 47907. btonnsen@purdue.edu

abstract.p: Although social communication skills are commonly delayed in children with neurogenetic syndromes, skill profiles in very young children are largely under-characterized, in part due to the lack of validated assessment measures appropriate for these populations. We addressed this gap by validating and applying a popular early social communication screening measure, the Communication and Symbolic Behavior Scales Developmental Profile â€“ Infant-Toddler Checklist (CSBS-ITC) in three previously understudied neurogenetic groups: Angelman, Prader-Willi, and Williams syndromes. Our results suggest that when used within the appropriate scope of screening and surveillance, the CSBS-ITC detects meaningful variability in skills across ages in young children with neurogenetic syndromes and may provide useful information about both individual- and population-level social communication profiles in these populations.
